document.docAuthor: Busanello, Dilson G. C. & Caron, Edilson
document.masterDocTitle: Redescription of the Type Species of Lithocharodes Sharp (Coleoptera: Staphylinidae: Staphylininae: Xantholinini), with Remarks on the Genus

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Redescription of the Type Species of Lithocharodes Sharp (Coleoptera: Staphylinidae: Staphylininae: Xantholinini), with Remarks on the Genus

subSubSection.paragraph:
Type Material.
The holotype is deposited in the British Museum of Natural History , London , UK ( Ulrich Irmler , University of Kiel , Germany , personal communication)
.

Material Examined.
Male, dissected, labels: (1) “Brasil, Pará , Uruará\Mata, II-III-2015,\Inverno, Serapilheira,\Reinaldo, Wully, Idielson,\col.” [white label, printed in black]. 1 male and 1 female , female dissected, same labels: (1) “ Brasil , Pará , Uruará\Pastagem, II-III-2015,\Inverno, Pitfall /sem iscas,\Reinaldo, Wully, Idielson,\col.” [white label, printed in black]. caption.paragraph:
Fig. 1.
Lithocharodes fuscipennis
, male dorsal habitus.

subSubSection.paragraph: Redescription. Maximum body length = 5.5 mm ; maximum elytral width = 0.7 mm . Body elongate, parallel-sided. Dorsal surface glossy; body light brown to reddish brown, elytra dark brown to black with apical quarter conspicuously paler except on elytral suture, abdominal segments VII and VIII darker, legs paler; some specimens with apical half of head and apical half of pronotum darker, similar to elytra and abdominal segments VII and VIII. Head and pronotum with impunctate longitudinal medial line ( Fig. 1 ).

caption.paragraph:
Figs. 20–23.
Lithocharodes fuscipennis
. 20–21) Aedeagus, ventral and dorsal views, respectively; 22–23) Apex of aedeagus, ventral and lateral views, respectively. A = ventral arm; B = dorsal arm; C = dorsal ring; D = ventral projections; E = membranous area. Scale bars: Figs. 20–21 = 0.5 mm; Figs. 22–23 = 0.2 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph: Distribution. The species was originally described from Pará (northern Brazil ) ( Sharp 1876 ). Subsequently, it was recorded in Amazonas ( Brazil ), Guatemala , Nicaragua , and Argentina ( Lynch 1884 ; Sharp 1885 ; Newton 2019 ). Here we extended its distribution in Brazil to the southeast ( Rio de Janeiro ) and south ( Paraná ).

Biological Notes. The species has
Xantholinus
- like habits. It can be found in manure and under rocks and leaves and frequents all kinds of plant detritus. It is a slow runner, barely lifting its abdomen, and never rolls up in a volute shape ( Lynch 1884 ).

Taxonomic Notes on the Genus. All characteristics listed by Smetana (1982) for the genus are corroborated, except for the following: 1) Base of apical palpomere of maxillary palpus 2/3 width of apex of palpomere 3 in
L. fuscipennis
; 2) Apical palpomere of maxillary palpus slightly shorter than palpomere 3, about 0.8 times in
L. fuscipennis
(listed by Smetana only in the key); 3) Superior line of hypomera fading out at 2/3–5/6 posteriorly and slightly deflected to ventral surface at level of procoxa, but not joining inferior line; 4) Punctures on apical portion of scutellum may have long setae in
L. fuscipennis
(up to five long setae were observed); 5) Tarsomere 5 as long as two preceding tarsomeres combined in
L. fuscipennis
; 6) Mesotarsomere 1 two times longer than mesotarsomere 2 in
L. fuscipennis
.

Diagnosis of the Genus.
Lithocharodes
differs from
Metolinus
,
Neoxantholinus
,
Stenistoderus
, and
Zeteotomus
by the apical maxillary palpomere slightly shorter than palpomere 3; from
Xantholinus
and
Leptacinus
by one or two subapical ctenidia on the meso- and metatibiae (except for
Lithocharodes longicollis LeConte, 1863
and
Lithocharodes densus Smetana, 1982
) and the developed and bifurcated parameres; and from
Somoleptus
by the pronotum widest across anterior third, with rounded and distinct anterior angles (Bordoni 1982; Smetana 1982 ;
Navarrete-Heredia et al. 2002
; Zhou and Zhou 2011 ).
Lithocharodes
differs from
Lissohypnus
by the apical maxillary palpomere slightly shorter than palpomere 3, and from
Neohypnus
by the metatibia with subapical and apical ctenidia ( Smetana 1982 ;
Navarrete-Heredia et al. 2002
).
